Ready to chow done, I unwrapped the small log and instantly realized that my burrito was ICE COLD. wtf? Warmed it up in the microwave, and went to town. Only meaning to eat half, I ate the entire damn thing. It was so good. Stomach feeling like it was gonna explode, I wobbled back to my desk in a mexi coma.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
This was a surprising five star burrito experience. From the outside it looks unassuming and right in line with the countless other food options in the area. But inside is a rather delicious burrito.

Don't be put off by the slightly high price for a regular burrito. $6.25 is a little higher than most places, but with that you get the works of meat, lettuce, beans, cheese, sour cream and rice. That's a super burrito elsewhere.

Four stars were attained when the guy behind the counter had no problem tossing in more lettuce and beans since I didn't want any of the last three.

Four and a half stars were attained when the chicken was freshly cut up as they were making my burrito. Not a drop of oil in sight. Tasted healthy too.

Four and three quarters stars were attained for offering wheat tortillas and black beans. 

Fifth star attained for what might have been a speed record in taking my order and delivering my food. One minute max.

A nice little mexican gem.
author: Jason B.

description:
Had a steak burrito here, and as much as it pains me to say it -- since it's an absolute shame -- this place is better than El Faro across the street. Burrito bowl's are only $6.75.

The food is served hot, fresh, and quick, and features a good salsa bar with a surprisingly great and addictive salsa verde. 

The quesadillas are not very good however -- there's not much cheese, the sour cream is served on the side, and they put tomatoes in it even though they aren't mentioned on the menu board. Also, the pork is awfully dry.

However, they don't nickel and dime you for extras like El Faro, and the place is just cleaner, the burrito has much less rice, and the steak is not oversalted like El Faro. In fact, you can get whatever extras you want for free. The staff is absurdly friendly.
author: Adam Z.

description: Great food, service, and salsa bar. Clean and quick. Large portions too.
author: Ben S.

description:
Pasilla does a good job for what it is, i mean dont come here expecting the typical cheesey beany giant burrito. They do have however, fresh ingrediants and decent sized portions.

I tasted a chicken and pork burrito when they catered our office. Both tasted good for me, but a bit heavier on the rice side than the typical burritos I eat. 

I also tried their tacos--delicious and had a lot of meat. 

I wished their food had a little more flavor to it, and by flavor i mean SPICY SPICY! I like my food spicy not hot, and their was no sizzle here. They had chopped up veggies in lieu of salsa which i found strange. Even stranger that they had it labeled "salsa"--am i missing something or is salsa usually tomatoey or at least spicy! 

Still, pretty good food and I will frequent this place.
author: Amy S.

description:
That was a pretty good burrito!  I enjoyed the vegetarian burrito with black beans, along with some of their spicy salsa, onions, cilantro, and lime from their well-stocked salsa bar.  I personally didn't find the tortilla (I had whole wheat) to be all that amazing, so I would recommend getting it in a bowl instead so you can add ingredients from the salsa bar without unwrapping your burrito and making it messier.  The price ($7.12 with tax) wasn't bad either, and at 1:00 the service was really fast.

However, I still prefer the many delicious options in the mission, and really missed enjoying an agua fresca with my burrito (they have bottled water and teas instead).  You can get both in the mission for less than just the burrito at Pasilla.  Pasilla is way closer to my office though, so I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Rachael S.

description:
Ever CRAVED something, it was so good?! I've gotten burritos from many a Mexican restaurant all over the Bay Area and SF, I keep going back to this place. All the others fail in comparison.

First Star: fresh ingrediants. Seriously, you can't replace quality for quantity, people aren't stupid.

Second Star: good service, the person at the counter always has a smile-why they are smiling is a whole nother story but as long as they are friendly and courteous when taking my order, I'm happy.

Third Star: it's clean, the floors and tables are always spotless. A good sign that the kitchen is the same. Hygiene IS important, nobody wants to get food poisoning after lunch, especially at work!

Fourth Star: good menu, they serve more than just good burritos. I've also had their spicy fish tacos-messy, but awesome. They do many dishes well, not just one or two...they get bonus points for their salsa. Any Mexican restaurant/stand/place that can't get their salsa right is an automatic "flag" for me. 

Fifth Star: location, location, location. I don't have to drudge into the Mission just to get a decent burrito, thank you for being downtown and closeby. Honestly, I'm very appreciative of how safe I feel getting to this place. Great for lunch or dinner, take out on the way home after a long day. 

Overall, I've raved about this place to coworkers, friends and family. It's a MUST, even if it's just for one visit.
author: Foo D.

description:
If you like bland-tastic and almost meatless burritos, come here.  Otherwise, Pasilla is a very disappointing destination for pork products.  On the "plus" side, Pasilla inspired me to create the Steve K. "Pork Products Hall of Shame" list.

Hits:

Tortilla: well-grilled.
Temperature: hot.
Size: moderate; definitely big enough for lunch.

Misses:

Meat: a small portion of bland roasted pork.  I hate having to ask "where's my pork at?"  I didn't spend almost $8 on lunch for a fucking veggie burrito.

Cheese: it was listed on the menu, but it was hiding.  Don't tease me, cheese.

Ingredient mix: "rice and beans" is not an ingredient mix.  The first third of the burrito had no meat at all.  None.  Fuck you, Pasilla.

Guac: $1.50 for guac means it shoulda represented.  I saw it peaking through here and there, but what little there was had a funky sour taste.

Lettuce: thankfully I spied this on the menu and asked them to omit it from my order.  Lettuce has NO place in a burrito.

Pico: I can't recall having had a burrito that omitted pico or some kind of sauce, but perhaps Pasilla is starting a new trend.  Die trend, die.

Rice: almost half of the burrito was full of bland white rice.  

Beans: I like black beans, but beans do not a burrito make.

What a fucking waste of calories.
author: Steve K.

description:
This is the kind of place that makes all of human society pass before you in a horrifying existential swirl.  Why, you ask?  Well, compare this to a Taqeria in the mission.  This is not a terrible burrito, but it's certainly bland and quite generic, all in English, and spelled out for you as if you've never been to a Taqeria in your life.

The reason?  as far as I can tell, it's the guys who work in the BofA building across the street.  The kind of guys who probably don't know that the mission exists and heard that "Mexican Food" was good.

How can people like this exist in San Francisco?  How?  It blows my mind to the point where I can only stare at them and chew my bland burrito in wonder...

Minus one additional star for looking like a chain (don't know if it actually is or not) and another star for charging for chips.
author: Nick A.

description:
Look, here's the deal.  I actually don't like giving positive reviews.  Call me an asshole. Most subjects of my reviews do.

However.

Pasilla. The menu is limited, just tacos, burritos, and burritos in a bowl.  Two kinds of salsa, one kind of guacamole. Apparently, no refried beans.

So why is Pasilla the only full menu (albeit a miniature one) I keep on my fridge?

Because the chicken tacos are delicious, and as Amanda F. points out, prepared with all fresh ingredients, and Larry, the owner-operator, bakes his taco shells instead of frying them. So, points for heart healthy proprietors. The quesadillas are fine, although I'd stay away from the steak, a little chewy.  Stick with the chicken.  He'll offer fat-free sour cream, whole wheat tortillas, and if you ask nicely (and order food for five), he'll deliver to your door.

I don't know what kind of business they do during the day.  I usually place my order about ten minutes before I'm ready to pass out from low-blood sugar levels (at around 7pm).  And Larry has my order ready in time to stave off hypoglycemic disaster.  When I go for pick-up there isn't much of a line, and I want to keep this place open. 

Bottom line, your choice is limited, and the food won't blow you away.  But if you care about nutrition, watch your wallet, and want something crunchy, hot, and most importantly, prepared (and even delivered) by a decent human being, go to Larry at Pasilla.

Keep it going, people. Screw Chipotle and Baja Fresh.  Give Larry some love.

There.  A mostly positive review.
author: Donny S.

description:
I needed a change from the thai and Mediterranean lined street that is Kearny and came across Pasilla. I actually never walk past Ayola and was surprised to see a few more restaurants beyond them. At first when I looked at Pasilla, I immediately put it in the category with horrible, americanized mexican food like Qdoba and Chipotle. Well... I was wrong. 

Though this place is catering more to the american palette, it is not horrible. It's quite tasty in fact and the prices are reasonable. The service is friendly and they have a complimentary salsa bar. YAY! I won't be here often, but it is always an option when I need a break from Thai and Greek food...
author: Jen D.

description: I have grabbed a burrito from this place once a week for the past year, and I have never had a bad burrito. Best value/ quality Mexican food in the area and the salsa bar is fantastic.
author: Evan L.

description:
I had a steak bowl (burrito w/out the tortilla) and it was good, three star good.  The fourth star is because they gave me free chips (so much for not eating a tortilla!), and 'cause it's their first week open.  
The manager/owner and the crew were working their butts off, much good luck to them.
author: Kiki R.

description: Honestly, the best $8.50 I've spent for a nice salad in the area in 5 years.  Delicious. Fresh.  The servers were great.  I definitely recommend eating here verses spending the money for less food at Chipotle.
author: jay a.

description:
I guess if Chipotle is your destination for "mexican food," then Pasilla is your place. Not only is it basically the same food (and one of those places that charges you for chips, although they have a salsa bar), but they even took inspiration from the name - Pasilla is another type of pepper.

I tried the chicken burrito and was not very impressed. But I don't like Chipotle either. Well, to end this on a positive note, it is better than the 360 burrito thing they replaced.
author: Neil K.

description: I always love getting away from the chain restaurants and finding better alternatives, and I think that Pasilla is one of the best substitutes to Chipotle. Their spicy grilled chicken bowl is filled with my favorites, and the proportion of each fits my liking perfectly. The bottom is layered with Spanish rice, but it's definitely not a large amount. The health freak in me loves that this bowl is more high protein and low carb. On top of that is a layer of beans, either black or pinto that are not too wet so that the rice gets soaked. Finally, they generously pile on the lettuce, pico de gallo, and chicken. The grilled chicken is extremely flavorful and you really get the grill taste in every bite. They also have a great selection of different salsas to add that extra kick, however spicy you want it to be. Pasilla has definitely become my go-to place for burrito bowls, and I definitely suggest splurging on a little guac to complete the entire thing!
author: Ashley T.

description: Got a steak and black bean burrito and some chips. I liked the salsa bar as well. Everything was pretty damn good. Nothing crazy special, but solid.
author: Andy D.

description:
Ok, I gave it a try 3 times... I don't know... I love working girls... but Pasilla is missing something. The fact they charge for guacamole and even the chips I find a bit bothersome.  I rather go to El Faro across the street. It is not bad at Pasilla, but it is still not quite there.   I am sure they will get the hang of things soon enough. I just hope they realize that it is kinda not cool to ask you if you want guacamole and not tell you it is costing you more... along with chips... they just don't mention it to you. Next thing you now what you ordered easily ends up costing you about $2.50 more.

I do like the chicken quesadilla though... spicy chicken... it is not that spicy, but it is tasty!
author: Amelia M.

description:
Ever since that fire closed down the international food court **CURSE THE GODS** I've been trying out new places around work. 

I've come here about five times now... this place is GOOD. Not only that, the owner is also a friendly guy. He works as a cook in back.

Anyways, despite feeling like a chain in terms of the design of the place (menus, uniforms, etc.), etc. -- it is not. It's independently owned -- which is always a plus in my book.

I always order the vegetarian burritos -- not because I'm vegitarian, but because it comes equipped with guacamole and sourcream by default (otherwise an extra $1 or so for each).. yes, I'm a cheap ass... but nevertheless, all the burritos are excellent. 

Best of all is the salsa bar. I just wish they packed bigger sauce containers... instead I have to pack four containers while I wait for my burrito and once I get my paper bag, I dump the containers in to hide them and pack four more... hahah... yeah I don't want to get any dirty stares!

---------------
edit 6/23/08

I came here a couple days ago and guess what... BIGGER SAUCE CONTAINERS! The gods have been listening!!
author: Edward Y.

description:
I (heart) this restaurant! I used to eat here weekly for lunch with the BF (sometimes more than once), but then he stopped working in downtown and I felt slightly foolish going in weekly without him. I guess I've always thought it was assumed that we went so frequently because I was there with him. When really, we went to feed my obsession with Mexican food. Haha.

Faves:
Steak & Chicken anything (their meat is sooo tender and flavorful)
Guacamole & Chips (their guac is soooo yummmmy)
Unlimited Salsa Bar (LOVE their hot carrots!)
Staff (super friendly and efficient)

It's a small restaurant with really limited seating, but if you're there for lunch, you can always walk up Pine and eat at the park.
author: Lezlee C.

description:
i do love this place. 

no, it is not "authentic" mexican. but its burrito bowl is very delicious! it's warm, juicy, with sour cream spread out on the rice (as opposed to a dollop on the side, knocking the dish off balance). extra lettuce makes it very refreshing, and most definitely try out the spicy chicken if you're a fan of hotness! 

also: free salsa, jicama "salad", and grilled jalapeno! definitely bring out the freshness on a stuffy day :)
author: Fiona S.

description: It was ok, I would go back if I was craving a burrito but nothing beats the mission district!!
author: Lewis F.

description:
I really wanted to like it because I heard it was opened by our friends at Working Girl.  It was the worst mexian food I have ever had.  I ordered the fish tacos, corn tortillas.  I asked for no cilanto.  I was told there was only a little bit in the salsa.  I asked for no salsa.

There was so much cilanto mixed into the guac and lettuce that I had to remove everything but the fish.  The fish was pretty bad, but the most surprising thing were the taco shells.  They were the kind you get at taco bell.  The pre-shaped/processed kind.  Also, it was supposed to come with some special sauce, not there.

I won't be back.  I'll give it one star because I like the people at Working Girl.
author: Juliana L.

description:
I've got such a palate for Fresh Mex it's ridiculous.  I come from the land of the east, where Willy's Mexican Grill and Moe's ran rampant in my awful and delicious diet.

So if you like cilantro and big burritos, you'll like Pasilla.  

And everyone in there is so freaking nice to me, I love it.  They're genuine and amazing.  

I can't comment much about their meats and etc, but daaaaang the salsa bar and gauc are super good.

Stay away if you like authentic Mexican and hit up El Faro across the street.  

Pasilla is super quick, even with large orders, a great place to pick up lunch for work or whatever event you might have!
author: Kari C.

description:
It's alright.  The customers are annoying and the counter staff yell loudly and impatiently.  But at least it's fast, and at least it's not a 360 anymore.  The doltish customer in front of me seriously had to ask what was in a steak burrito. 

"I donno, man, probably some steak and some beans and some other shit.", I wanted to say.  

My burrito was ready before I managed to fill some salsa cups, and the counter lady kept yelling my number very impatiently.  

"I know lady, I can hear you.  It's just a burrito, not a bomb or something.  I'll pick it up in due time."

Lots of airy rice but overall OK for an anglicized burrito.  A lot like a burrito a guerro like me might make at home actually!  I swear there was even Newman's Own Italian on the lettuce, sour cream, yellow cheese, red onion.  All the white boy fixin's!  Given that the ingredients seemed to be of high quality and certainly tasted fine, I guess it works.
author: Jared L.

description: After starting a new job in the area, I've been experimenting with nearby restaurants during my lunch breaks. Pasilla Grill was one of the biggest let downs to date. My veggie burrito bowl was bland and overpriced, and not even the addition of fajita veggies and more guacamole than should ever be on one dish could make any kind of real flavor happen. I'll keep experimenting, but won't revisit this failure ever again.
author: Lindsay J.

description:
It's easy to compare this place to Chipotle, so I will.  I'd say it's maybe not as good as Chipotle but I don't think Chipotle is all that anyways, so go here if Chipotle is not within walking distance.  It's priced similarly as Chipotle, and the menu is very similar.  

I ordered the burrito bowl and I am annoyed that they don't use recyclable or compostable containers.  At least they don't appear to be so (no recycle or biodegradable/compostable signs on the containers).
author: Christy I.

description: I work directly across the street from Pasilla Mexican Grill and get a vegetarian Pasilla bowl at least twice a week, sometimes more. It's my go-to spot for an affordable, filling, vegetarian lunch. The ingredients are super fresh with a small salsa bar for unlimited fresh salsa (multiple types), limes, peppers, cilantro and other Mexican condiments. They also make a point to use local and organic ingredients when possible. The Pasilla bowl is my absolute favorite item to order...rice, choice of black or pinto beans, guacamole, cheese (not the best...shredded), high quality lettuce and salsa (I always go without the sour cream) for $7.12 after tax! And the best part is, I've asked them to stop using plastic bags for takeout for the past six months, and now they only use brown paper bags! Fast food CAN be healthy and sustainable.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Being a non-native who hasn't quite trained her palate to handle the grease, beans, cheese, spice and cilantro combination, I appreciate being near a place where I can pick up healthy, fresh 'Mexican' food whenever Donny S. has the craving. We don't hate ourselves after eating their delish (baked, not fried) crispy chicken tacos, and the service is always friendly, prompt and extremely helpful.

The owner will deliver for orders of 5 or more if you don't live too far away, and I agree - the jicama salsa is definitely a big free plus. I would opt for chicken dishes rather than steak, as they're much tastier - and the chips-guac-salsa combination is pretty damn tasty.
author: Amanda F.

description: My officemate and I get lunch at Pasilla probably once a week, possibly slightly less often. I dig this place, it's like Chipotle with actual food. The chipotle adobo dressing on the salad is aces, and the salsas can't be beat. Everything I've tried at Pasilla has been delicious -- I am primarily vegetarian, so I can speak only to their animal-free offerings, but I am given to understand the chicken quesadilla is also excellent. Prices are average for the FiDi, service is fast and friendly.
author: Ell B.

description:
I stumbled upon Pasilla while looking for a good place to grab a late takeout lunch.  You know... the kind where the food is still fresh at 2 PM.

Pasilla fit the bill.  The service was fast and friendly.  The food was made-to-order.  While I would not consider it a truly authentic Mexican restaurant, they make a tasty and filling burrito.

I will definitely be back!
author: Ashley S.

description:
I'm a fan. Particularly compared to the other options for Mexican food in the Financial District, Pasilla is tops. I second people's exhortations not to compare it to Mission taquerias -- it just ain't that kind of place. Better comparisons would be to La Salsa, Una Mas, Chipotle, and I think Pasilla is better than any of those.

I've only ever ordered soft chicken tacos, but I've really liked them, and I'm confident the other food would be just as tasty. Ingredients are fresh and nicely prepared. The salsas are tasty. One small minus: Chips don't come with the three-taco orders (but that's just as well if you're counting calories or watching carbs). A very clean place, probably helped by the fact that there's next to no seating -- Pasilla is very to-go-oriented.

Nom nom nom!
author: Tara M.

description:
Since I work across the street, I've had Pasilla numerous times (closest place to eat dinner).

Food:  The burritos are decent at best but their guacamole isn't bad.  The meat isn't the best quality (Chipotle has better meat) but you can't tell as much because the taste is covered up by the guacamole, salsa, sour cream, etc. in the burritos.  I would only recommend this place if you wanted a quick bite of Mexican food for dinner in the financial district.

Service:  Always friendly service.
author: Paul C.

description: I usually get the chicken bowl ($7.39 after tax). Big portions and love the salsa bar.  Seems cleaner than most other Mexican places.  Menu is pretty similar to Chipotle.
author: Paul I.

description:
This is a new joint that inhabits the former 360 Degrees Burritos front.  The menu claims to use "... top shelf meats, poultry and fish and always use organic when possible."  

The menu is very basic -- you have a choice of meat:

Chx
Spicy chx
Steak
Pork
Fish (tacos only)
Vegetarian (everything BUT tacos)

And choice of meat delivery vehicle:

Burrito
Taco
Bowl
Quesadilla

I kicked things off with a spicy chx burrito, straight off the menu.  It was tasty, although not remarkably so, and not very spicy.  The one thing they do that bugs me is put lettuce on their burritos -- mixed with sour cream, it just gets soggy.  (Plus, I don't like lettuce on burritos. What's that about? It's not a salad or a sandwich.)  

The guy at the counter was super nice and helpful, though.  Not a bad experience overall -- will be back to try my other meat delivery options, on those days when I can settle into a nice relaxing mexi-food coma without worrying about passing out in a pesky meeting.
author: Rob W.

description:
One of my coworkers picked up lunch here yesterday.  From the looks of her chicken quesadilla, I wanted to go get one for myself today.

I ordered the spicy chicken quesadilla $5.95 with a a side of guac $1.50...and got some of their jicama salsa at the bar.  Those who know me well know that I have a pretty large appetite for a girl my size.  I'm known to eat larger quantities of food than the men I date =)  Is that something to be proud of?  Not sure.  Well, I was full with just eating 2/3 of my meal.  I'd say it was pretty filling.

The quesadilla is packed with tasty chicken and wasn't super greasy as many typical Mexican places have a ton of.  I thought their style of quesadilla was on the healthier side...it also had cilantro, tomato and some other Mexican seasonings.  Unfortunately, they failed to include a little container of sour cream (which my co-worker seems to receive every time with her order of quesadilla [yeah, she ordered the same thing....two days in a row]).  The guac was so-so.  It was indeed fresh, but it wasn't anything special in taste.  

I'd be back there to try their other items.  I really liked how the dishes I've seen them prepare appear to be on the healthier side.
author: Michelle N.

description: Great place for a fast lunch to go in the Financial District.  Staff is friendly and the food always tastes fresh.  I stop by here at least once a week and am always satisfied.
author: Jason D.

description:
el faro=salt.
pasilla=real mexican flavors,great salsas and chips.  no wait.
author: Timothy S.

description:
This place is lame. For starters, no mixing and matching on the tacos (one fish, one chicken, etc.), even with same priced items. And then no mixing on soft/crispy shells. So I ordered fish tacos like my friend did. By the way, his total was $7.27 and they did not let him slide on the two cents. The fish did not taste fresh and parts of it were grey. The one redeemable quality of this place is the guacamole, which is excellent.

There are better places to go, even in the financial district.
author: Crockett J.

description: Spicy chicken burrito with guacamole... $9 is a bit much, especially if they're going to add lettuce as filler. It was pretty good though.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I would give this one star, but the place just opened, so I leave open the possibility for getting better.  I also only tried a burrito, and there may be some other things on the menu that are better.

That being said, this was one of the worst burritos I've had.  Too much rice (which tasted like white rice with a little hot sauce on it), the pork was bland, the chips were store bought.  Overall there are many better places to grab a burrito downtown - Tlaloc, Si Senor, not to mention El Faro which is right across the street.
author: Kevin R.

description:
I've only tried this place a couple of times, but I'm going to go ahead and give them five stars.  I've ordered the same thing twice--three fish tacos (that's one order) on soft flour tortillas for six bucks.  Tortillas are freshly heated, and the tacos are loaded with veggies, pico de gallo, and guac.  This is a lot of food for six bucks in the FiDi, and it's healthy to boot.  The folks behind the counter seem eager to please, and they have a salsa bar that's not huge (this is a hole-in-the-wall place, after all) but suits my needs.  I got one container of good mild salsa verde and another of onions and cilantro.  I am a happy luncher.

UPDATE:  I've been coming here regularly for several weeks now.  Mostly I get the chicken soft tacos.  Three nice-sized tacos with grilled chix and romaine, sour cream, and diced tomatoes for six bucks.  --Plus, the folks behind the counter are unfailingly nice.  I continue to be a happy luncher.
author: Earline A.

description:
This place is fantastic.  The pasilla bowl is HUGE, and only $5.95 (beans, rice, great chicken/pork/steak, sour cream, cheese, salsa, lettuce).  Awesome salsa bar with Jicama salsa, three other kinds of salsa, cilantro, onion.

This is probably the best lunch you're gonna get in the Financial for under $7.
author: Spencer M.

description: Spicy chicken burrito has great flavor. Large but doesn't leave you feeling stuffed. Salsa actually has some kick.
author: Gary W.

description: I had a burrito here a couple weeks ago, it was good, but not so good that I've gone back yet. I probably will in the future, just not yet.
author: C D.

description:
I haven't tried anything else but the spicy chicken tacos but yum, so good.  And it really does have a kick. 

Now I find myself craving it.
author: Claire C.

description: Before coming here, I read a lot of the reviews and had pretty much decided that I wanted to try their Spicy Chicken Burrito Bowl. I saw Yelpers who declared it uber-spicy, as well as those who dismissed it as bland. Well, as a fan of all things spicy, I found it very mild. Luckily, I loaded up on hot sauce and peppers from their bar, so was able to elevate it to the appropriate heat for moi. But I will say that the food was extremely fresh, and the portions very generous, so I was rather impressed. And even though it kind of defeats the purpose of ordering a bowl, go ahead and buy a side of chips to make the world a more nacho place.
author: Gregor G.

description:
Stop comparing this place to taquerias in the Mission.  That's a pointless and irrelevant comparison.  What Pasilla is though is the best burrito in the Financial District.  Admittedly, the bar is much lower with the FD caveat, but let's compare apples to apples.  I'm not going to hop on a flight to Mexico at lunch time, and I'm not going to bike to the Mission either.  Here's why it's tops:

Fresh ingredients
Grilled tortilla
Open salsa bar with good salsa
Not a rip off for the FD ($8.25 with guac)
Very large burrito

I look at Chipotle as the median for all taquerias.  Is Chipotle great?  Nah, but it'll do in a pinch, and at least you know what you're going to get.  If a place is worse than Chipotle, it's not worth going back to, and Pasillas is clearly better than Chipotle.
author: Adam B.

description: Not interested. The menu is limited (no chile relleno, for one) and the prices are a little high. There is a very nice condiments/salsa bar off to the side of the room, but the place is often so busy that there are all these guys in pleated Dockers leaning on it and making it inaccessible. Plus, it's at hip-level, which is a little gross when you realize how many people's butts are inches from the food. I'm hypersensitive about this stuff because I've seen a lot of gross things happen in condiments areas in San Francisco. Across the street is another taco joint, El Faro, which I'm not particularly crazy about either (I gave them equal 2 star ratings), but at least it's a little more authentic seeming than Pasilla.
author: Heidi G.

description: Nice people, fast, and good burritos.  The spicy chicken anything is the way to go, but my vegetarian friend likes their veggie burrito as well.
author: Yosh F.

description: I went back here today.... This has become one of my favorite lunch spots in just a few short days. I have gotten everyone at my salon into it as well. We love the burrito  bowls here and the whole wheat tortillas!! the customer service is always great and the food always comes out fast.
author: Wes P.

description: This place is amazing. Not sure what people were thinking when they gave this place 3 stars, but for our order, they were spot on and fantastic. Unanimous consensus from the whole office that this place is fantastic! Quick, accurate delivery. And the huge servings of chips, salsa and guac were a crowd favorite. Yummy burritos, yummy guac. Definitely adding this place to our menu rotation-- they ousted the old Mexican place in one fell swoop. Way to go!
author: Lindsay F.

description: I love this place!  The Manager, Larry, makes me feel like I'm at a 4 star restaurant every single time!  The veggie burrito is my favorite and I love their green salsa.  My biggest complaint is the lack of seating, but for $5.95, I can't complain.  I just wish I could get it on the weekend!
author: Brandy B.

description: The beef and chicken soft tacos are not bad. Make sure to request soft shells. The hard shells are like Old El Paso taco shells taken from a box at the local grocery store. It would be Very Nice if they includes chips with the order instead of charging $1.50. Even El Faros throws in the chips.
author: Marty M.

description: If the commercialized Chipotle was actually good, used fresh ingredients and did not leave you with gut bomb after every meal. Pasilla is a breath of fresh air for burritos. Menu options are divided among burritos, bowls, tacos and quesadillas. Choices of meat are the standard steak, chicken, pork, vegetarian and one other I forgot. Steak burrito was very delicious. Fresh ingredients, whole pieces of tender steak, not to much guacamole or sour cream. And the right level of kick to the burrito. Prices are on par with El Faro right across the street, and for once a burrito will not leave you slumped over in your chair.
author: Ryan G.

description: Pretty good for Mexican food on dirty Kearney. I like it better than El Faro across the street.  I've only ever had a pasilla bowl and a burrito.  I like how they have whole wheat tortilla options, that makes my day :) You get to choose between pinto beans or black beans and I always opt out for the sour cream.  They have a little salsa bar too with a few different options.  Their guacamole is pretty good too (you have to pay for the guac.  The cashiers are super friendly too, I think they may be the owners.
author: Jenny W.

description: the free Jicama salsa is what keeps making me go back- in addition to the yummy food!
author: Shuba B.

description: the times I've eaten here, I end up with the worst digestive discomfort which includes the worst  heartburn... I'll be avoiding this place.
author: Tina K.

description: Hoo boy is their spicy chicken spicy. Just ate a burrito bowl and my mouth is on fire! Recommend the regular chicken burrito bowl with light cheese and sour cream on the side. I like to go nuts with the add ons bar: love the jicama salsa, fresh cilantro and lime.
author: Yiming R.

description:
Meh. The spicy chicken was okay, but their rice sucked. Like, it ruined the food log. And the ingredients were all segregated. Like whole parts of the tortilla were a no-sour-cream zone, or chicken only, no guacamole allowed! That's one of my pet peeves with burritos. 

However, the service was shockingly friendly and their salsa bar kicked ass. So, given a severe burrito craving and short amount of time in which to satisfy it, I guess I'd go back.
author: Sage R.

description: By way of San Diego & Los Angeles, San Francisco doesn't have any stake to claim their Mexican Food is the best.  So I decided to try this place out and it was good.  The price was mediocre.  I did like the self serve salsa tray.  I had the chicken burrito and it was tasty along with some chips that came with it.  An overall okay experience.
author: Limzer L.

description: Don't go here expecting authentic Mexican food.  However, the food is all fresh and well-prepared.  I tried a few of the salsa and they were all tasty. The burritos are great, not sloppy or too heavy in one ingredient.  The service was great as the guy who took our order was very accommodating and helpful.  Also, don't plan to sit down and eat here ESPECIALLY with a big group.  There are only two tables in the place with two chairs at each.  We were lucky enough to have a couple get up just as we finished ordering.  The prices were reasonable, the joint was clean, and the location was great.  I'd certainly go back here or recommend it to others.
author: Megan B.

description: One of my favorite place to grab lunch at in the city. Everything on their menu is very flavorful and hearty. Their Burrito are great. Their Quesadillas are packed with flavor and not over grilled. The burrito bowls are very filling. The best part is you get a lot of bang for your buck.
author: Marco M.

description: This is a solid option for lunch or cheap dinner in FiDi. The ingredients taste fresh and pretty high quality. I really like the chicken - whatever they marinate it in, it's pretty good. Burritos are a little more than $6.00, and you can get a burrito bowl for the same price. It's really not authentic, more of a Chipotle-ish type restaurant. Check it out!
author: Rohan N.

description:
Hey! I'm the first to Yelp this one! Woohoo!
I tried Pasilla today. It is in the same spot where 360 was on Kearny (at Pine). Interior is very similar to 360 and menu is also, so expect Chipotle - like simplicity in the selection, although the food is prepared to order so expect a small wait for your order.
I had a slab (for those of you that don't know a slab = a burrito, please see www.burritoeater.com). I had the Spicy Chicken with pinto beans, no sour cream and guac. Not bad. Here is my review:
- Overall a good slab. A bit heavy on the rice. Rice is prepared Spanish style, so it it is fairly tasty.
- Chicken was tasty. Marinated and had a nice zing to it.
- Guac was good to pretty good. No complaints.
- Pinto beans - I think Chipotle cooks their Pintos with a bit of bacon which is what makes them so awesome. I don't think they attempt to replicate this feat here, so they are just ok.
- Salsas: they do have a fresh salsa bar so that you can help yourself. The salsas are not bad, but not mind blowing either. 

All in all I would say this is a welcome addition to the nearest Mexican grilles (El Faro is across the street) and is certainly worth a try.
author: Matt H.

description:
The food was just OK. I really liked the chips and guacamole, but the burrito bowl left something to be desired. The meat was overly seasoned and the lettuce was dry and seemed out of place in the dish. The rice and pinto beans were good, though.
Oddly, I got a stomachache within an hour of eating here, but I did not get sick. Will probably only return for chips and guac.
author: Jen O.

description: I'm a sucker for the spicy chicken burritos! OMG the best. I mean if they weren't good then why would i crave them so much? because they are!
author: Lucero A.

description: Pretty solid carne asada burrito - guac was tasty..... and their salsas are really good.. They had a great jicama salsa that was soooo good - I love jicama!  And it's only 2.5 blocks from my house!
author: A B.

description: great tacos!  I hope they add Tamales to their menu!  These are the same people who own Working Girls Cafes.  What a great option for anyone in the Financial District!
author: Kevin D.

description: Basically you pay for air.  The burrito is so small and empty...literally.  I'm use to HUGE burritos filled with meat in the Mission and even at Chipotle.  This place is a nice corner spot, but that is about it.
author: Elliot Y.

description: This is such a great staple in the Financial District.  Food is fresh, the folks who work there are nice and caring and informative. They use local and organic ingredients when possible.  Just wonderful! They allow plenty of options, wheat or regular tortilla, different kinds of beans, sour cream, guac, etc. The burritos just taste fresh and they are generous in size. Pasilla, I love you.
author: Jenna K.

description: The best thing on the menu is the Pasilla Spicy Chicken Burrito Bowl.  Their burritos are only soso, nothing very special.  Throw on some of that jicama from their salsa bar, load up on hot sauce, add some jalepenos, and order a bag of tortilla chips to go with it.  It's a flavor explosion in your mouth... which can't be too healthy, but once every few weeks is alright.  Convenience and quick service is a plus.  3.5 stars
author: Randall L.

description: This place really keeps getting better and better. You can now get any sort of salsa you want in the burrito. I do all sort of frankenburrito modifications when I order, and the superfriendly staff unflappably smiles and just jots down whatever I want. It seems to be getting busier in there, so it's nice to see word's getting around.
author: Aaron L.

description: Basing this on just the burrito bowl, they don't give you a whole lot.  After picking through the mound of lettuce (I left the rice out), I found the treasure of the rest of the meal.  It wasn't much, but it tasted good.  Good black beans and wonderful guac.
author: Kool B.

description: I go to school on this street so I've came here a couple times to grab a bite . The spicy chicken burrito tastes okay . The cheese and salsa quesedilla wasn't that great though .. it was kind of lacking flavor . I'm giving this place an extra star because the guy here is pretty nice because he gave my classmates and I free sodas with our purchases . He also threw in some spicy salsa and guacamole in my quesedilla for free . This might not be the best Mexican place but it's not that bad and it's definitely better than El Faro .
author: Eileen L.

description:
What can you expect from a downtown Mexica "grill"? I'll tell you what: it's expensive, large, and fit for consumption.

Don't go to Pasilla if you want the best Mexican cuisine in town, and don't expect much more than a full meal that satisfies your hunger.

Don't get the chips, they are grade-C. Stick with the basics, the chicken burrito I'm now digesting was a fine choice.

There's much better out there, but if you're nearby and in a rush to get back to the office, pick up Pasilla.
author: DJ D.

description: As far as fast food goes, this is probably as good as it is going to get.  I liked the simple menu and the quick service.  the portions were plenty generous and the people who work there pretty hospitable.  The food was a little bland but I guess it is Americanized for the masses.
author: Javier O.

description:
This is my favorite fast FiDi lunch spot, and I probably come in for the spicy chicken soft tacos about once a week.  Service is fast and everyone's nice, pricing is reasonable and the ingredients are very fresh.  
I've tried several of their other offerings as well, but keep coming back for the chicken soft tacos; the spices are perfect and the whole thing is just the right size for a filling but not stuffing lunch.  Other yelpers have pointed out that it's not very "authentic Mexican food", but who cares?  Call it "Mexican Fusion" or something, and enjoy your lunch.
author: Jared H.

description:
Lame Place

For one you can not separate your taco order.  If you want crispy and soft tacos you better be ready to eat 3 of each because you can't combine.  I wanted 1 soft and 2 crispy and the guy was like "We don't do that."  What do you mean "You Don't Do That"? You have crispy shells and soft tortillas, I do not understand why I can't have 1 soft and 2 crispy.  Lame !  Same goes for my buddy too, we all want a combo, but "Pasilla don't do dat."  Go across the street to El Faro, way better, faster, hotter employees. 
Oh by the way - this guy CHARGES FOR CHIPS - at a mexican restaurant - charging for chips?  Thats like paying for a fortune cookie at a chinese restaurant.  If you are ok with these things go for it, but I am not.  El Faro is the best place to go and it has bathrooms !!!
author: Chris B.

description:
Very disappointed with the new establishment - not sure why it changed from 360 burrito, but the differences were very clear. I ordered the spicy chicken burrito thinking that that it would somewhat spicy - turned out to be mostly rice and hardly a hint of spicyness.  I asked for guacamole and they said it was $1.50.  I surely thought it was a mistake and that they were quoting me the side dip price, but no, it costs 1.50 to smear some guac on the burrito.  I suggested to the manager that they were overpricing the guacamole, but they replied "well we give you beans and cheese for free, thats why the gauc has to cost 1.50" 

sure buddy.  I miss 360... I guess its across the street to El Faro or Chipotle.
author: Michael C.

description:
Working in the Financial District, it's not always easy to get a nice lunch, at a reasonable price. The Pasilla Mexican Grill, is a place where this is not only possible, but guaranteed.

They offer a wide range of Mexican cuisine. I've had their grilled chicken casadilla bowl. It came with large chunks of succulent, grilled chicken,  rice, your choice of pinto or black beans, chopped onions, tomatoes, and a large dollop of sour cream. It was very fresh-tasting, filling, and the price was right (under $7).

Today, I went back. I ordered a steak casadilla, with a side of chips and guacamole. The grilled steak was cut into small, but very flavorful
pieces. It was folded into a warm, soft flour tortilla, along with melted jack cheese, chopped onions, tomatoes, and diced cilantro. It was definitely a 'class-A' item on their menu.

They really go all-out to please their customers. The service is quick, and the staff is marvelous. This is a tiny eatery, with limited seating available. But, that's only a small strike against them. Everything else about this place, is top-notch.

If you like fresh, quickly-prepared, and delicious Mexican food at affordable prices, then the Pasilla Mexican Grill is your best bet, anywhere in the Financial District.
author: Sonya S.

description: Delicious, fresher ingredients than other places, fast service, friendly staff, and modestly priced. Great for lunch or dinner.
author: Denny B.

description: I love this place!! Sure, the guac costs extra, but three tacos for $6? That's amazing. The best thing here though is the jicama salsa--I actually took home extra because it made me so happy. Try it out, the service is great and you won't be disappointed.
author: Caitlin C.

description: Yum yum yum. I love this place! The staff is friendly and quick and their options are fresh and healthy. I love their bowls!
author: Jessica H.

description: great food, simple menu, and the owner(s) are nice.. They also own "working girls cafe" right around the corner.  prob the best so far!
author: Fady A.

description: This place is a step down from Taco Bell, might say they are fresh but the taste tells the real story. Taco shell had a funny flavor. $6 for a dry taco?
author: Vanessa N.

description: Bland.  So completely bland.  Mexican food for the whitest people only.  Mexican food from the food court of a mall in deepest Wisconsin or Minnesota or anywhere else that mayonnaise is considered a spice.  Which is not to say it's bad.  Just don't fall asleep while you eat.
author: Stephen N.

description: I love places that have salsa bars and don't charge you extra for it, so one star for that. The mild and medium salsas have the best flavor, at least in my opinion and really that's the one that matters :) They get another star because they replaced CRAPPY, CRAPPY, CRAPPY 360 burrito. I can't express enough how much I hate that place. But this review is not about them. Another star for having fish tacos on the menu. However, the fish tacos were a little fishy tasting and I spotted some scales through the guacomole blanket that covered my tacos. They were pretty decent though and GINOURMOUS! I had to get three of them and seriously I would have been good with just one. I ate one whole one, ate just the fish out of the second one, and I sold one to my coworker, which was pretty awesome cuz I made $2 back and didnt have to throw it away. I haven't tried anything else yet, but my coworker is a big fan of their rice and beans. Booyah.
author: Amanda S.

description: Had the chicken burrito (no sour cream, no cheese). It was pretty good and tasted fresh. People were nice. Service was fast. Burrito was cheap. Will go again. 'Nuff said.
author: Patrick G.

description: Meh, this place was okay.  A $6.25 burrito is a good deal, but it was nothing memorable.  The 'hot' salsa was anything but, and we waited quite a while for a burrito despite the fact that the place was empty.  Probably would not go out of my way to try this place, but if you work nearby Kearney, have a burrito fixation, and have only a few bucks, I guess it's worth a try.
author: James S.
